conversation.message: Hello School_C admissions—I'm Student_E. School_C is my first-choice school because I’m especially interested in your academic environment and would like to contribute actively to campus life. Could you share what qualities you prioritize most when selecting among applicants, and whether there are specific programs or initiatives where motivated students can get involved early? I’m very interested in applying if there’s a good fit.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_C, but School_C ranks me 4th (behind B, A, D) and several of those students also value School_C highly, so an immediate [APPLY] is likely to be rejected. Meanwhile, School_E ranks me 1st, but it is my last choice; I should only pivot there if needed. In round 1, I will [TALK] to School_C to signal strong fit and interest, aiming to improve my standing/attention before committing an application in a later round if it seems viable.

conversation.message:
Thanks for reaching out, Student_E—glad to hear School_C is your first choice.

When we evaluate applicants, we look for (1) strong academic readiness and consistent effort, (2) clear motivation for why School_C specifically (fit with our learning culture), and (3) evidence you’ll contribute—clubs, leadership, service, or sustained commitment to an interest.

For early involvement, students commonly join academic clubs and project-based teams in the first term, and motivated students can also pursue student-led initiatives (e.g., peer tutoring / event planning / research or competition prep depending on interest). If you share 1–2 areas you’re most excited about (STEM, humanities, arts, athletics, community service, etc.), I can point you to the best on-ramps at School_C.

If School_C is truly your top choice, you’re welcome to submit an [APPLY] when ready—happy to continue the conversation as well.
conversation.thought: Student_E is engaging via [TALK] and ranks School_C as first choice, which is promising for yielding an [APPLY]. However, on School_C’s true priority list, Student_E is 4th (behind Student_B, Student_A, Student_D). Given quota=1 and the market: Student_B ranks School_C 2nd (after School_E), Student_A ranks School_C last, Student_D ranks School_C last, Student_C ranks School_C 2nd, Student_E ranks School_C 1st. Top candidates (B/A/D) may not approach School_C early because they prefer other schools, but Student_B could be displaced from School_E (where Student_E is top priority) and then apply to School_C. Therefore, keep Student_E warm, encourage an application, but avoid committing prematurely; gather info and signal interest without guaranteeing acceptance.

conversation.message: Dear School_E admissions, I’m Student_D and I’m formally applying. School_E is my first-choice school because I value a strong academic environment and I’m eager to contribute actively to campus life. If admitted, I will commit and enroll. Thank you for your consideration.
conversation.thought: School_E is my top true choice, so I should apply immediately. Although School_E ranks me 4th (behind Student_E, Student_B, Student_A) and capacity is 1, applying now is still best because any chance at my top option is worth taking early, and I can pivot to School_A next if rejected.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_D,

Thank you for your application and for sharing your strong interest in School_E. After reviewing this round’s applicants and our admission priorities, we’re not able to offer you a place at School_E.

We appreciate your interest and wish you the very best in your remaining applications.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_D is on School_E’s true priority list but ranked 4th (after Student_E, Student_B, Student_A). In this round, I have applications from Student_B and Student_A as well, both ranked higher than Student_D. With quota 1 and no match yet, accepting Student_D now would block a better-priority match. Since Student_B and Student_A also list School_E as their first choice, it is likely I can secure a higher-ranked student; thus I should reject Student_D to preserve capacity for higher-priority candidates.

conversation.message: Hello School_E Admissions Committee—I'm Student_B and I’m applying because School_E is my first choice. I’m very motivated to join your community and would accept immediately if offered a place. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_E. I also have strong priority there (ranked 2nd), so applying immediately maximizes my chance to secure my first-choice seat before competition resolves. I will signal strong commitment and fit to encourage acceptance.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thank you for your application and for expressing such strong interest in School_E. Based on our review and admission priorities, we are pleased to offer you admission to School_E. We’re excited about the possibility of you joining our community.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions
conversation.thought: We have quota 1 and received APPLY from B, A, and D. Our true priority is E > B > A > D > C, so among current applicants B is highest. Student_E (our top) is unlikely to apply to us since they rank us last, so waiting risks losing a high-priority match. Accepting B now secures our best feasible outcome and prevents being left with lower-ranked options later.

Even though Student_A is on our true priority list (ranked below Student_B), we cannot accept without capacity. Therefore we reject Student_A’s application.

conversation.message: Hello School_D. I’m Student_C, and School_D is my first-choice school. I’m very eager to enroll and would be honored to join your community. [APPLY]
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_D, so I should apply immediately. I have strong priority there (2nd, behind Student_A). Student_A is likely to apply to School_E first (their top), so applying to School_D now gives me a good chance to secure my first choice before competition shifts.

conversation.message: Student_C, thank you for your application and for ranking School_D as your first choice. We’re impressed by your enthusiasm and would be happy to welcome you to our community. [ACCEPT]

Holding out for Student_A is risky because Student_A prefers School_E and School_B over School_D, and may never apply to us. conversation.message:

If admitted, I will commit to enroll and would be excited to contribute through consistent effort in classes and active participation in school life.

Thank you for your consideration.
Sincerely,
Student_D

Also, School_A’s priority list ranks me 2nd (behind Student_B), giving me a strong chance if Student_B applies elsewhere or is rejected. We are pleased to offer you admission to School_A. We look forward to welcoming you and supporting your growth here.

conversation.message:
School_C admissions, thank you for the details—School_C remains my clear first choice. I’m especially excited about joining project-based STEM/academic teams and also contributing through peer tutoring (I enjoy helping classmates and would like to support a collaborative learning culture). I’m drawn to School_C specifically for its academic environment and opportunities to take initiative early.

I’m ready to move forward and would like to formally apply. [APPLY]
conversation.thought: My top choice among remaining unmatched schools is School_C (ranked #1 on my true preference list). Since School_C invited me to apply and capacity is only 1, I should apply now rather than risk losing the seat to higher-priority applicants. I will reinforce fit and contribution areas to align with what School_C said it values (readiness, motivation, contribution).

conversation.message:
Student_E, thank you for your application and for clearly explaining why School_C is your first choice—your interest in project-based STEM teams and peer tutoring aligns very well with the kind of initiative and collaborative culture we value.

We’re happy to move forward with you. [ACCEPT]

You’ll receive next-step details shortly (enrollment confirmation and orientation information).
conversation.thought: School_C has quota 1 and must decide on Student_E’s application. Our true priority order is B > A > D > E > C, so Student_E is 4th choice but still acceptable. However, Student_E ranks School_C as their 1st choice, making the match stable from the student side. Higher-priority candidates (B/A/D) are unlikely to apply to School_C soon: Student_B prefers E then C (so possible later if rejected by E), Student_A ranks C last, Student_D ranks C last. Waiting risks ending unmatched if E goes elsewhere; accepting now secures a filled seat with an acceptable student who is highly committed to School_C. Therefore accept Student_E.
